description:
Pteropus alecto, commonly known as the black flying fox, is a species of fruit bat native to northern Australia and southern New Guinea. It is a member of the family Pteropodidae, which are also known as Old World fruit bats or megabats.

The black flying fox is a large bat, with a wingspan that can reach up to 1.5 meters (5 feet). It has a robust, black-colored body with a distinct, dog-like facial appearance. The fur on its body is dense and can range in color from black to dark brown or even reddish-brown.

These bats are highly social and can form large colonies, sometimes numbering in the thousands, roosting in trees or caves. They are primarily nocturnal and play an important ecological role as pollinators and seed dispersers, feeding on a variety of fruits, flowers, and nectar.

The black flying fox is considered a vital component of the ecosystems it inhabits, contributing to the maintenance of forest health and biodiversity. However, the species has faced threats from habitat loss, hunting, and the impacts of climate change, leading to concerns about its long-term conservation status.
